metadata.summary: Apple's official Human Interface Guidelines for implementing Dark Mode, a systemwide appearance setting that uses a dark color palette to provide comfortable viewing in low-light environments. The document covers best practices, color adaptations, icons and images, text legibility, and platform-specific considerations.

supportedPlatforms.notes: Full Dark Mode support with base and elevated background colors
Full Dark Mode support with base and elevated background colors
Full Dark Mode support with desktop tinting feature

definition.description: Dark Mode is a systemwide appearance setting that uses a dark color palette to provide a comfortable viewing experience tailored for low-light environments.
definition.userBehavior: In iOS, iPadOS, macOS, and tvOS, people often choose Dark Mode as their default interface style, and they generally expect all apps and games to respect their preference.
definition.systemBehavior: In Dark Mode, the system uses a dark color palette for all screens, views, menus, and controls, and may also use greater perceptual contrast to make foreground content stand out against the darker backgrounds.

guidelines.rule: Avoid offering an app-specific appearance setting
guidelines.rationale: An app-specific appearance mode option creates more work for people because they have to adjust more than one setting to get the appearance they want. Worse, they may think your app is broken because it doesn't respond to their systemwide appearance choice.

guidelines.rule: Ensure that your app looks good in both appearance modes
guidelines.rationale: In addition to using one mode or the other, people can choose the Auto appearance setting, which switches between the light and dark appearances as conditions change throughout the day, potentially while your app is running.

guidelines.rule: Test your content to make sure that it remains comfortably legible in both appearance modes
guidelines.rationale: In Dark Mode with Increase Contrast and Reduce Transparency turned on (both separately and together), you may find places where dark text is less legible when it's on a dark background. Turning on Increase Contrast in Dark Mode can result in reduced visual contrast between dark text and a dark background.
accessibilityConsiderations: Test with both settings enabled simultaneously
People with strong vision might still be able to read lower contrast text, but such text could be illegible for many

guidelines.rule: In rare cases, consider using only a dark appearance in the interface
guidelines.rationale: It can make sense for an app that supports immersive media viewing to use a permanently dark appearance that lets the UI recede and helps people focus on the media.

example.description: The Stocks app uses a dark-only appearance

overview.description: The color palette in Dark Mode includes dimmer background colors and brighter foreground colors.
overview.importantNote: These colors aren't necessarily inversions of their light counterparts: while many colors are inverted, some are not.

adaptiveColors.guideline: Embrace colors that adapt to the current appearance

customColors.implementation: Add a Color Set asset to your app's asset catalog in Xcode, and specify the bright and dim variants of the color.
customColors.warning: Avoid using hard-coded color values or colors that don't adapt.

contrastRequirements.guideline: Aim for sufficient color contrast in all appearances

recommendedContrastRatio.scope: For custom foreground and background colors, especially in small text

benefits: Ensures foreground content stands out from the background
Helps content meet recommended accessibility guidelines
contrastRequirements.systemColorsBenefit: Using system-defined colors can help you achieve a good contrast ratio between your foreground and background content.

whiteBackgrounds.guideline: Soften the color of white backgrounds
whiteBackgrounds.implementation: If you display a content image that includes a white background, consider slightly darkening the image to prevent the background from glowing in the surrounding Dark Mode context.

iOS_iPadOS.description: In Dark Mode, the system uses two sets of background colors — called base and elevated — to enhance the perception of depth when one dark interface is layered above another.

types.name: base
types.purpose: Making background interfaces appear to recede
types.usage: Default background for primary content areas

types.name: elevated
types.purpose: Making foreground interfaces appear to advance

dynamicBehavior.description: Dark Mode is dynamic, which means that the background color automatically changes from base to elevated when an interface is in the foreground, such as a popover or modal sheet.
additionalUseCases: Visual separation between apps in a multitasking environment
Visual separation between windows in a multiple-window context

iOS_iPadOS.warning: Using a custom background color can make it harder for people to perceive these system-provided visual distinctions.

desktopTinting.description: When people choose the graphite accent color in General settings, macOS causes window backgrounds to pick up color from the current desktop picture.
desktopTinting.name: desktop tinting
desktopTinting.effect: A subtle effect that helps windows blend more harmoniously with their surrounding content.

transparencyGuidelines.guideline: Include some transparency in custom component backgrounds when appropriate
transparencyGuidelines.rationale: Transparency lets your components pick up color from the window background when desktop tinting is active, creating a visual harmony that can persist even when the desktop picture changes.
when: Custom component has a visible background or bezel
Component is in a neutral state (not using color)
whenNot: Component is in a state that uses color
Reason: Can cause the component's color to fluctuate when the window background adjusts to a different location on the desktop or when the desktop picture changes

benefits: Work well in both appearance modes when using dynamic colors to tint them
sfSymbols.systemBehavior: The system uses SF Symbols (which automatically adapt to Dark Mode) and full-color images that are optimized for both the light and dark appearances.

interfaceIcons.guideline: Design separate interface icons for the light and dark appearances if necessary

examples.lightAppearance: May need a subtle dark outline to contrast well with a light background
examples.darkAppearance: May need no outline when displaying on a dark background
Might need a slight border to make the edge visible against a dark background

fullColorImages.guideline: Make sure full-color images and icons look good in both appearances
approach: Use the same asset if it looks good in both light and dark appearances
If an asset looks good in only one mode, modify the asset or create separate light and dark assets
Use asset catalogs to combine your assets into a single named image

commonIssues.darkBackground: On a dark background, illustrations may have poor contrast and many details may be lost
commonIssues.solution: Adjust illustration for better contrast on a dark background

overview.description: The system uses vibrancy and increased contrast to maintain the legibility of text on darker backgrounds.

labelColors.guideline: Use the system-provided label colors for labels
labelColors.behavior: The primary, secondary, tertiary, and quaternary label colors adapt automatically to the light and dark appearances.

systemViews.guideline: Use system views to draw text fields and text views
benefits: System views and controls make your app's text look good on all backgrounds
Adjusting automatically for the presence or absence of vibrancy
systemViews.recommendation: When possible, use a system-provided view to display text instead of drawing the text yourself.
